At Fri, 21 Nov 2008 00:51:53 +0000,
Mike Kelly <mike@...> wrote:
=
> 
> Erik Hetzner wrote:
> > The Accept header is really the client=E2=80=
=99s business, not the server=E2=80=99s.
> > If you want to change the =E2=
=80=98context=E2=80=99, then change the URI.
> >   
> http://www.w3.org/Pro=
tocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html
> 
> "The Accept request-header field can=
 be used to specify certain media 
> types which are acceptable for the res=
ponse. Accept headers can be used 
> to indicate that the request is specif=
ically limited to a small set of 
> desired types, as in the case of a requ=
est for an in-line image."
> 
> Am I missing something?

Sorry - I wasn=E2=
=80=99t clear. If the server wants to define a =E2=80=98context=E2=80=99 in=

which only a particular response is acceptable, then that context
should b=
e reflected in a different URI.

To use an example: if I understand you, yo=
u are saying that there are
times when you want to ensure that a client rec=
eives a JPEG
representation of URI <A> - a resource that has 2 representati=
ons, PNG
and JPEG. You want to have a mechanism to ensure that a client sen=
ds a
specific Accept header so that it can only receive that JPEG.

What I =
am trying to say is: if you want to ensure that a client
receives a JPEG ve=
rsion of <A> then you need another URI, <B>, which
has only 1 representatio=
n, a JPEG. The JPEG representations of <A> and
<B> might always be the same=
, but if you want to tell the client that
it needs to have a JPEG, then you=
 need to have a different URI.

> >> One thing that bothers me about using =
the URIs for that, is it
> >> becomes unclear whether a PUT to /document.pd=
f is an update that
> >> will be reflected in /document.doc and /document.x=
ml - this is
> >> requiring the users, and caching mechanisms to be applica=
tion aware.
> >>     
> 
> Does anyone have any comments on this?

Not me, =
sorry. I don=E2=80=99t have enough knowledge of caches.

best,
Erik Hetzner=
